ya i would have totally missed the description if not for the Piazza lol

@ChandraSapkota Great! One extra requirement I ended up thinking of while I was creating the manual was the need to select a location for the app (so the orders/pre-orders can get associated with the proper location)
That is a good one @OmarRamos, nice!! I'll add that as well
One more that i thought was an option where, "every 100/200 (we can choose) points you can have a dessert for free"

Another one, After 5000 points, we don;t know what happens with the points, so after 5000 points when you are in VIP level, you can redeem your points, "convert the points earned into giftcards where each points equal to penny
Another, for VIP customers, "free delivery within 5 miles radius"

Hmmm, the dessert for free option one might be doable, but the point redemption one would add quite a bit of additional complexity (because then you'd have to keep track of point usage) and the free delivery one we wouldn't really be able to test/verify so it probably wouldn't work either.

ok, ya we don't want anything that would me the project more complex, so probably we can add just couple (2/3) supplementary requirements one being location, other free dessert and next we can come up with something easy

@MuraliRaju As a sidebar, I'm currently doing some research about using MySQL with Android and I'm seeing very little information on creating a direct MySQL connection within the Java code, all of the approaches I'm seeing show creating a simple API on the server side and having the Android code create an HTTP Client and send POST requests and receive JSON in response.
How man do we need.
3/4 should do it
I listed a few additional reports as well in the Initial User Manual draft above (they're listed at the end)
I like the most sold items one
Omar - Mt SQL sounds complicated for our project.
Any other options to store data.
Any talk in Piaz.
Supliment:
1. Free dessert
2. Bessellers

MySQL would actually not be too bad (from my perspective, since I have the hosting service already available and could create the API endpoints that could be talked to over HTTP). The only internal to Android data storage option we would have is SQLite, but that wouldn't lend itself to a central data store (with multiple cart locations)
Lets implement this round with SQLite.
